channel.title: Geography - Arctic Tundra
channel.description:
Hey guys, We have to do this presentation with a minimum of 4 slides based on a ecosystem of our choice. I've chosen Arctic Tundra, If any of you guys can post facts that I can include, I'd be ecstatic. Thanks. I'll upload my powerpoint presentation once I've finished it so you guys can see. ^_^
EDIT: I've done a bit, I've had to upload it since MSCP doesn't allow .ppt extensions Link: [url=https://mega.co.nz/#!cotxQKaA!IEEXO0cvl6qLHeagZb1IBENBGzhdA1Iq1K6nSVbkLV0]CLICK ME[/url]

item.title: Geography - Arctic Tundra
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

[quote=“Lil_Smok3r, post:5, topic:533580”]Thanks RiiPiin, I appreciate it.

  • Adding it now.
    EDIT: Changed a bit so it’s not all C&P.
    What I’m researching now: Why is the ecosystem being destroyed[/quote]Apparently I am the only one here going to major in Biology…

So the ecosystem is being destroyed because of Global Warming. Global warming is starting to melt the frozen layer of earth, known as “permafrost.” This layer is important to the environment as species, both plant and animal that live there, are adapted to colder temperature. When the plants die off, the primary consumers die off. This affects the whole ecological pyramid. Its a chain reaction.

In fact, if we were to eradicate all insects off the face of the Earth, all life on earth would die in 50 years. If we were to eradicate humans off the face of the earth, live would thrive. Environmental change always comes back to humans in some shape or form.

Read full topic

[/quote]
If so, then the tundra is a desert. A desert isn’t a place with sand, but with very little rainfall.[/quote]
yeah, cold deserts.

item.title: Geography - Arctic Tundra
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

No trees grow there.

The Tundra is permanently covered by a layer of frozen soil, or permafrost. The permafrost itself can reach between 300 to 1,500 feet deep. The permafrost severely hinders makes plant growth in the tundra.

Day Length: Because of the Tundra’s northern position, during the winter, sometimes only a few hours or less of sunlight occur. In contrast, in the summer, the sun is almost up 24 hours a day

There are two different types of Tundra, Polar Tundra and Arctic Tundra. Polar Tundra is found close to the earth’s poles and Arctic Tundra is found above the tree level in high mountain ranges.

The average yearly precipitation in the Tundra is usually less than 15 inches.

Read full topic
